Welcome to my workshop website, here you can find dates/times for when a programming workshop will be held, as well as resources from my content as well as links to other sites which I've found of great value.

As a long time and entirely self taught programmer, I've noticed many of the roadblocks which come up in the path to mastering what you want within the vast world of programming. So far, I find Python to be the most reliable programming language for people to:
1. Learn quickly
1. Use effectively
1. Master perpetually
1. Accomplish the same things as other languages

Best of all, Python is completely free and open source. Head over to the Official Python website and download a copy for yourself: [Official Python Website](https://www.python.org/) 
Just move your mouse over the "Downloads" heading and click the button "Python 2.7.10". Feel free to download Python 3.4.3, but my workshop will focus on Python 2.7.10, as this is the main version in use in much of scientific programming.

# Here are some invaluable resources:
[Automate The Boring Stuff](https://automatetheboringstuff.com/), by Al Sweigart  
A great book offered online free as html, hones in on simple automation of boring tasks, ignoring much of the obtruse programming theory.

[Learn Python the Hard Way](http://learnpythonthehardway.org/book/), by Zed Shaw  
First resource recommended to me for learning Python years ago, and for good reason. This is the definitive introduction to Python programming, with its direct and immediately rewarding style of "Learn this, now try it." While it may seem difficult at first, when you're off on your own code and things aren't working right you'll appreciate having learned to troubleshoot and analyze code logic.

[Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/)  
Every programmer's dirty little secret. Stack Overflow is a community driven Q&A board that has been used so frequently that you're likely never to find a question that has gone unanswered. If you want to save time, I recommend just using [DuckDuckGo](http://www.duckduckgo.com/) and searching "python (your question here)". The search engine then loads the top queries from Stack Overflow and lists them across the top of the search page. Clicking on a relevant question will then drop down the best answer for that question.

More to come.
